programName: Mechanical Engineering with a Specialization in Materials Science and Engineering (B.S.)
fullProgramDescription: The Mechanical Engineering with a Specialization in Materials Science and Engineering major is designed to provide students with a comprehensive education in mechanical engineering with a focus on the properties, applications, and processing of materials. The program includes coursework in mechanics, thermodynamics, materials science, and engineering design, as well as laboratory and computational experiences.
shortProgramDescription: This major prepares students for careers in mechanical engineering with a specialization in materials science and engineering, focusing on the properties and applications of various materials.
classHighlights: The program begins with foundational courses in engineering, including Engineering Graphics (MAE3), Introduction to Thermodynamics (MAE11), and Introduction to Materials Science for Engineers (MAE101).
Students then progress to core mechanical engineering courses, including Mechanics of Solids (MAE101), Dynamics (MAE30B), and Mechanical Engineering Laboratory (MAE107).

Materials science and engineering coursework includes Materials Science Laboratory (MAE112), Materials Selection and Failure (MAE156A), and additional electives that cover various aspects of materials science.
Students also complete mathematics and science requirements, including Calculus (MATH20A-B-C-D), Physics (PHYS2A-B-C), and Chemistry (CHEM6A-B-C).
The program also includes a range of technical electives, allowing students to explore specialized topics in mechanical engineering and materials science.
Laboratory and computational experiences are integrated throughout the curriculum, providing hands-on experience with materials characterization, mechanical testing, and engineering design.

Upper-division coursework includes Mechanical Engineering Design (MAE156B), Mechanical Engineering Systems (MAE170), and additional electives that build on the foundational knowledge gained in earlier courses.
learningOutcomes: Apply fundamental principles of mechanics, thermodynamics, and materials science to solve engineering problems.
Design and conduct experiments to characterize materials and mechanical systems.
Analyze and interpret data from materials science and mechanical engineering experiments.
Understand the properties, applications, and processing of various materials.
Communicate technical information effectively through written reports and oral presentations.
Work effectively in teams to design and develop mechanical systems and products.
additionalInformation: Students must complete a series of required courses in mechanical engineering and materials science, as well as mathematics and science requirements. The program is designed to be completed in four years, with a typical course load of12-16 units per quarter.
